messages.content: hi! do you know google cel?

Hi! Yes, I'm familiar with Google CEL (Common Expression Language). It's a non-Turing-complete expression language designed by Google for evaluating simple expressions in a fast, portable, and safe way. Here are some key points:

**What it is:**
- A lightweight expression language for evaluating conditions and transformations
- Designed to be embedded in applications, frameworks, and services
- Originally developed at Google and used in many Google products/services

**Key characteristics:**
- **Non-Turing-complete** — no loops or recursion, so expressions always terminate
- **Type-checked** — expressions are parsed and type-checked before evaluation
- **Fast** — designed for high-performance evaluation (nanosecond to microsecond range)
- **Memory-safe** — bounded resource consumption
- **Portable** — implementations exist in Go, C++, Java, Python, Rust, and more

**Common use cases:**
- **Security policies** (e.g., Google IAM conditions, Firebase security rules)
- **API filtering** (e.g., Google Cloud API `filter` parameters)
- **Kubernetes** (e.g., validation admission policies, Gateway API route matching)
- **Envoy proxy** — RBAC and routing rules
- **Configuration validation**

**Syntax examples:**
```cel
// Simple comparison
request.auth.claims.email == "user@example.com"

// List membership
request.method in ["GET", "POST"]

// String operations
resource.name.startsWith("/admin")

// Conditional
size(request.headers["Authorization"]) > 0

// Macros (like comprehensions)
request.auth.claims.groups.exists(g, g == "admin")
```

Is there something specific you'd like to do with CEL? For example, are you looking to:
- Integrate a CEL evaluator into a project?
- Write CEL expressions for a specific platform?
- Build something that uses CEL for user-defined rules?

Let me know and I can help! 🚀

yeh. we need a D cel library. I'm thinking "decel" lol. we don't have one yet... to start with, can you set up the dub logic for this in the root folder? if you write a Makefile you can run dub/dmd via testrunner, dfmt for formatting, dscanner, unit-threaded... do you need search engine access for this? I can hook that up

Great name — "decel" 😄 Love it!

I'm pretty familiar with D tooling (dub, dmd, dfmt, dscanner, unit-threaded), so no need for search engine access right now. Let me set up the full project structure.

Let me first check if there's anything already in the repo:

function.arguments: {"question": "What files exist in this repository? Give me a complete listing.", "pattern": "*"}
function.name: scout

🔧 **Tool call:** `scout`
```json
{
  "pattern": "*",
  "question": "What files exist in this repository? Give me a complete listing."
}
```
**Result:**
```json
{
  "answer": "Based on the provided content, I can only see **one file** in this repository:\n\n1. **.forge/session.json** \u2014 A session configuration file containing conversation history, request logs, and metadata about interactions with an AI model.\n\nThis appears to be a session tracking file for a tool called \"Forge,\" but no other repository files are included in the contents provided to me. To give you a complete listing of all files in the repository, I would need access to additional file contents or a directory listing.",
  "files_examined": 1,
  "model": "anthropic/claude-haiku-4.5",
  "success": true
}
```

Fresh repo — perfect. Let me set up the full project structure with dub, Makefile, and all the tooling.

<edit file="dub.sdl">
name "decel"
description "A Google Common Expression Language (CEL) implementation for D"
authors "decel contributors"
license "BSL-1.0"

targetType "library"
targetPath "build/lib"

sourcePaths ["source"]
importPaths ["source"]

buildTypes {
	unittest {
		dflags ["-unittest"]
	}
}

configuration "library" {
	targetType "library"
}

configuration "unittest" {
	targetType "executable"
	targetPath "build/test"
	mainSourceFile "source/test_runner.d"

	dependency "unit-threaded" {
		version "~>2.1"
	}
}
</edit>

<edit file="source/decel/package.d">
/++
 + decel - A Google Common Expression Language (CEL) implementation for D.
 +
 + CEL is a non-Turing-complete expression language designed for fast, portable,
 + and safe evaluation of simple expressions.
 +
 + See_Also: https://cel.dev/
 +/
module decel;
</edit>

<edit file="source/test_runner.d">
/++
 + Test runner entry point for unit-threaded.
 +/
import unit_threaded;

mixin runTestsMain!(
    "decel",
);
</edit>

<edit file="Makefile">
# decel - Google CEL for D
# ========================

DUB      ?= dub
DFMT     ?= dfmt
DSCANNER ?= dscanner

# Directories
BUILD_DIR  := build
SOURCE_DIR := source

# Colors for output
GREEN  := \033[0;32m
RED    := \033[0;31m
YELLOW := \033[0;33m
RESET  := \033[0m

.PHONY: all build test unittest format format-check lint clean help

# ── Default ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

all: build

# ── Build ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

build: ## Build the library
	@echo "$(GREEN)Building decel...$(RESET)"
	$(DUB) build

# ── Testing ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

test: unittest lint format-check ## Run all checks (tests + lint + format)
	@echo "$(GREEN)All checks passed!$(RESET)"

unittest: ## Run unit tests via unit-threaded
	@echo "$(GREEN)Running unit tests...$(RESET)"
	$(DUB) test

# ── Formatting ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────

format: ## Format source code with dfmt
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Formatting...$(RESET)"
	find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' | xargs $(DFMT) -i

format-check: ## Check formatting without modifying files
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Checking formatting...$(RESET)"
	@find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' | xargs $(DFMT) --check && \
		echo "$(GREEN)Formatting OK$(RESET)" || \
		(echo "$(RED)Formatting issues found. Run 'make format' to fix.$(RESET)" && exit 1)

# ── Linting ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

lint: ## Run dscanner static analysis
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Running dscanner...$(RESET)"
	$(DSCANNER) --styleCheck $(SOURCE_DIR)/ && \
		echo "$(GREEN)Lint OK$(RESET)" || \
		(echo "$(RED)Lint issues found.$(RESET)" && exit 1)

# ── Cleanup ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

clean: ## Remove build artifacts
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Cleaning...$(RESET)"
	rm -rf $(BUILD_DIR) .dub
	@echo "$(GREEN)Clean!$(RESET)"

# ── Help ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

help: ## Show this help
	@grep -E '^[a-zA-Z_-]+:.*?## .*$$' $(MAKEFILE_LIST) | \
		awk 'BEGIN {FS = ":.*?## "}; {printf "  $(GREEN)%-15s$(RESET) %s\n", $$1, $$2}'
</edit>

<edit file=".gitignore">
# Build artifacts
build/
.dub/

# Editor files
*.swp
*~
.vscode/
.idea/

# OS files
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db
</edit>

<commit message="Set up decel project structure with dub, Makefile, and tooling

- dub.sdl: library config with unit-threaded test configuration
- Makefile: build, test, format (dfmt), lint (dscanner) targets
- source/decel/package.d: root module stub
- source/test_runner.d: unit-threaded entry point
- .gitignore: build artifacts and editor files" />

Here's what I set up:

```
decel/
├── dub.sdl              # Package config (library + unittest config)
├── Makefile             # Build orchestration
├── .gitignore           # Build artifacts, editor files
└── source/
    ├── decel/
    │   └── package.d    # Root module (decel)
    └── test_runner.d    # unit-threaded entry point
```

**Makefile targets:**

| Target | Description |
|---|---|
| `make build` | Build the library via `dub build` |
| `make test` | Run all checks (unittest + lint + format-check) |
| `make unittest` | Run unit tests via `dub test` (unit-threaded) |
| `make format` | Format with `dfmt -i` |
| `make format-check` | Check formatting (CI-friendly, no modifications) |
| `make lint` | Static analysis via `dscanner --styleCheck` |
| `make clean` | Remove build artifacts |
| `make help` | Show available targets |

The `make test` target is the one the test runner will use — it chains unittest → lint → format-check so everything gets validated in one shot.

Ready to start building the CEL implementation whenever you are! The typical first steps would be a **lexer/tokenizer** for CEL syntax. Want to dive in?
Hang on. :edits: Okay, you should be able to run tests now.

messages.content: Looks good! Maybe a bit verbose if it does that every time you run it? It should output almost nothing in the happy case.

Good point — the Makefile is chatty with all those echo/color lines. Let me make it quiet in the happy path:

<edit file="Makefile">
<search>
# decel - Google CEL for D
# ========================

DUB      ?= dub
DFMT     ?= dfmt
DSCANNER ?= dscanner

# Directories
BUILD_DIR  := build
SOURCE_DIR := source

# Colors for output
GREEN  := \033[0;32m
RED    := \033[0;31m
YELLOW := \033[0;33m
RESET  := \033[0m

.PHONY: all build test unittest format format-check lint clean help

# ── Default ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

all: build

# ── Build ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

build: ## Build the library
	@echo "$(GREEN)Building decel...$(RESET)"
	$(DUB) build

# ── Testing ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

test: unittest lint format-check ## Run all checks (tests + lint + format)
	@echo "$(GREEN)All checks passed!$(RESET)"

unittest: ## Run unit tests via unit-threaded
	@echo "$(GREEN)Running unit tests...$(RESET)"
	$(DUB) test

# ── Formatting ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────

format: ## Format source code with dfmt
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Formatting...$(RESET)"
	find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' | xargs $(DFMT) -i

format-check: ## Check formatting without modifying files
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Checking formatting...$(RESET)"
	@find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' | xargs $(DFMT) && \
		echo "$(GREEN)Formatting OK$(RESET)" || \
		(echo "$(RED)Formatting issues found. Run 'make format' to fix.$(RESET)" && exit 1)

# ── Linting ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

lint: ## Run dscanner static analysis
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Running dscanner...$(RESET)"
	$(DSCANNER) --styleCheck $(SOURCE_DIR)/ && \
		echo "$(GREEN)Lint OK$(RESET)" || \
		(echo "$(RED)Lint issues found.$(RESET)" && exit 1)

# ── Cleanup ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

clean: ## Remove build artifacts
	@echo "$(YELLOW)Cleaning...$(RESET)"
	rm -rf $(BUILD_DIR) .dub
	@echo "$(GREEN)Clean!$(RESET)"

# ── Help ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

help: ## Show this help
	@grep -E '^[a-zA-Z_-]+:.*?## .*$$' $(MAKEFILE_LIST) | \
		awk 'BEGIN {FS = ":.*?## "}; {printf "  $(GREEN)%-15s$(RESET) %s\n", $$1, $$2}'
</search>
<replace>
# decel - Google CEL for D
# ========================

DUB      ?= dub
DFMT     ?= dfmt
DSCANNER ?= dscanner

# Directories
BUILD_DIR  := build
SOURCE_DIR := source

.PHONY: all build test unittest format format-check lint clean help

# ── Default ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

all: build

# ── Build ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

build: ## Build the library
	@$(DUB) build -q

# ── Testing ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

test: unittest lint format-check ## Run all checks (tests + lint + format)

unittest: ## Run unit tests via unit-threaded
	@$(DUB) test -q

# ── Formatting ───────────────────────────────────────────────────────

format: ## Format source code with dfmt
	@find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' | xargs $(DFMT) -i

format-check: ## Check formatting without modifying files
	@find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' | xargs $(DFMT) --check

# ── Linting ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

lint: ## Run dscanner static analysis
	@$(DSCANNER) --styleCheck $(SOURCE_DIR)/

# ── Cleanup ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

clean: ## Remove build artifacts
	@rm -rf $(BUILD_DIR) .dub

# ── Help ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────

help: ## Show this help
	@grep -E '^[a-zA-Z_-]+:.*?## .*$$' $(MAKEFILE_LIST) | \
		awk 'BEGIN {FS = ":.*?## "}; {printf "  %-15s %s\n", $$1, $$2}'
</replace>
</edit>

<run_tests/>

❌ `run_tests` failed:

No tests to run
OK!


--- stderr ---
Unrecognized option --check
make: *** [Makefile:36: format-check] Fehler 123

Ah, this version of `dfmt` doesn't support `--check`. Let me fix that — I'll use a diff-based approach instead:

<edit file="Makefile">
<search>
format-check: ## Check formatting without modifying files
	@find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' | xargs $(DFMT) --check
</search>
<replace>
format-check: ## Check formatting without modifying files
	@find $(SOURCE_DIR) -name '*.d' -exec sh -c \
		'for f; do $(DFMT) "$$f" | diff -q "$$f" - > /dev/null || { echo "$$f needs formatting"; exit 1; }; done' _ {} +
</replace>
</edit>

<run_tests/>
<commit message="Quiet Makefile output, fix dfmt format-check for compatibility" />
